授業目的:
A KALEIDOSCOPE OF JAPANESE CINEMA
This course intends to introduce students to the fascinating variety of Japanese cinema through a number of films representing different genres, themes and directors, including anime, and explore ways in which cinema offers a perspective into history, society and culture.
到達目標: The main objective of this course is to help students deepen their understanding of Japanese cinema and provide them with basic scholarship to discuss one of the world's most important film cultures.
授業方法:
Online format:On-demand Btype(w/o timetable). Information regarding the format of this class:
The class will be conducted entirely through LUNA.
Every class students will find materials and homework relevant to the week's lesson and contents together with explanations through .doc/ pdf / mp4 files.
The instructor will also provide relevant internet links for study and self-study.
Students will be required to prepare and submit homework through LUNA and/ or the instructor's Kwansei e-mail address before a given deadline.
The instructor will be available for simultaneous consultation through mail and LUNA during the duration of the class to maximise students' understanding and performance.
Students can also contact the instructor at any other time through mail and/or LUNA.

第1回:
Introduction to Japanese Cinema.
Historical Outline.
From silent cinema to "benshi" to talkies.
Genres in Japanese Cinema.
Early Japanese Animation: "Kamakura Gatana" (1917).

Research: Cinema outline in the students' own countries.
(Materials for the first class will be uploaded here on the same day).
第2回:
Classical Japanese cinema: an overview of the Masters
Ozu, Mizoguchi, Naruse, Makino, Yamanaka, Gosho.
"Sisters of Gion" (Mizoguchi, 1936) : in- class film viewing.
Images of Kyoto in the film.
Homework: Students will be assigned a film by one of these directors to watch outside class for this session.
A film by Ozu, Mizoguchi, Naruse, Makino, Yamanaka or Gosho.
第3回:
Interwar modernism and social critique.
Historical overview through different cinema clips and discussion.
Cinema in transition: actress Takako Irie and her roles through time ( modern girl,"moga", Kurosawa's suffering war woman, "bakeneko henshin", cat monster transformation in horror films).
Literature in film: Tanizaki and Kawabata.
Reading a short story by Kawabata
第4回:
A Forgotten Master: Shimizu Hiroshi.
Social types, economic depression, Korean forced labourers, the situation of women.
In- class film viewing: "Arigato-san" (1936)
第5回:
Cinema and the war. Example clips.
Propaganda and Anime
Short anime in-class film viewing: "Spider and Tulip" (1943)
Students will be required to watch "Momotaro's Divine Sea Warriors"  (1945) as homework.
第6回:
A Forgotten Master: Shimizu Hiroshi
Postwar Neo- realism.
A ruined country through the cinema lens: the black market, the issue of war orphans, "pan- pan" girls.
In- class film viewing: "Children of the Beehive" (1948)
第7回:
Postwar Japan: Reconstructing the industry under the American occupation.
Cinema highlights: clips.
The Golden Age of Japanese cinema: Kinoshita, Kurosawa, Mizoguchi, Ozu.
Foreign recognition.
Note: Students will be assigned a film by one of these directors to watch outside class for this session.
第8回:
The Japanese New Wave: breaking with the old studio system.
Social trends and cinema.Examples.
Film Noir: Yakuza in the 60s.
Shinoda's "Pale Flower".
In-class film viewing.
第9回:
The age of "Tokusatsu": Godzilla, Mothra and Ultraman.
"Manga Eiga" and "Japanimation".
Osamu Tezuka: Astro Boy.
Influences from the Takarazuka Revue on Tezuka's work.
Takarazuka as acting school.
Presence of manga and anime in general culture.
第10回:
Studio Ghibli: Miyazaki and Takahata.
"My Neighbour Totoro" and "Grave of the Fireflies".
Background and their far-reaching influences.
第11回:
Dream and Reality in Satoshi Kon's work.
"Perfect Blue" and "Millenium Actress".
Shorts contrast: Kon / Shinkai
"Paprika" (2006): in- class film viewing.
第12回:
Motifs in Makoto Shinkai's work.
A look at this working style: "V-Conto" and music.
"She and Her Cat" (1999) : in- class viewing.
第13回:
Kyoto Animation Studios: importance and relevant work.
Example clips.
Seiyuu, voice actors as idols.

評価.備考Note0:
Students are expected to attend all classes and participate actively in each session.
Due to the extensive nature of the subject, a number of films or clips from films will have to be watched outside class.
A series of compulsory readings and/ or worksheets and handouts will be assigned as preparation for the following class and must be read and prepared.
Students will have to write an essay on a film of their own choice from any period or genre.
The instructor will provide more information about the requirements of the essay at the beginning of the course.
Students will have to write a compulsory fieldwork report about an outing related to either a cinematic or cultural experience in Japan.
Maximum number of absences: 3
